I directed this multi-year comparative analysis, digging into environmental policy effectiveness across 12 metropolitan areas in North America and Europe. I wrangled a research team of 9 faculty members, 4 postdoctoral fellows, and 16 graduate students, and together we collected mixed-methods data‚Äîfrom surveys of 3,800 residents and interviews with 240 policymakers to spatial analysis using GIS software. (It felt a bit like assembling a continent-sized puzzle.)

üí∞ The project was fueled by a $2.4M grant from the NSF and European Research Council. We shipped 22 peer-reviewed publications and 3 policy briefs that were adopted by municipal governments. I presented the findings at 15 international conferences and wove them into graduate curricula at partner institutions. We also built a database for longitudinal tracking, and a 5-year follow-up study is now underway.

‚ú® It was a massive, collaborative effort that turned complex data into real-world policy impact.

---

**Interdisciplinary Initiative on Neuroscience and Educational Outcomes**  
üß† Co-Principal Investigator | 2019 ‚Äì 2024

I teamed up with neuroscientists and education researchers on this project exploring the neural correlates of learning in adolescents. We tackled data collection from 1,600 students across 28 schools, using EEG technology, standardized assessments, and classroom observations‚Äîthink EEG caps, focus groups, and a lot of carefully synchronized schedules.

üìà Backed by $1.8M from the Department of Education, the work generated 14 co-authored publications with combined citations soaring past 600. It was a true blend of brain science and classroom practice, proving that interdisciplinary curiosity can spark real insight into how students learn.
